criteria: Application of Special Limits in Problem Solving
descriptions: Student demonstrates no understanding of special limits such as (sin(x))/x and (1-cos(x))/x as x approaches 0.
Student shows minimal understanding of special limits, struggling to identify or define them.
Student identifies special limits but has difficulty applying them in simple problems.
Student correctly applies special limits in straightforward problems, showing a basic understanding.
Student demonstrates a strong understanding of special limits, applying them effectively in a variety of problems.
Student exhibits comprehensive understanding of special limits, applying them creatively and accurately in complex problems and providing clear explanations.
Student is unable to attempt any proof of special limits.
Student attempts to prove special limits but uses incorrect methods or makes significant errors.
Student shows some progress in proving special limits but struggles with key steps or justifications.
Student provides a mostly correct proof of special limits, with minor errors or omissions.
Student provides a clear and correct proof of special limits, demonstrating a solid understanding of the underlying principles.
Student presents a rigorous and elegant proof of special limits, explaining each step with precision and insight.
Student cannot apply special limits to solve any related problems.
Student attempts to use special limits in problem-solving but is largely unsuccessful.
Student uses special limits in simple problems, but makes frequent errors or requires assistance.
Student solves problems using special limits with reasonable accuracy and efficiency.
Student skillfully applies special limits to solve a variety of complex problems.
Student demonstrates mastery in applying special limits, solving challenging problems with creativity and offering alternative solution strategies.
